text: This is a list of battalions of the Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment), which existed as an infantry regiment of the British Army from 1881 to 1961. ==Original composition== When the 3rd (The East Kent) Regiment of Foot became the Buffs (East Kent Regiment) in 1881 under the Cardwell-Childers reforms of the British Armed Forces, four pre-existent militia and volunteer battalions of Kent were integrated into the structure of the regiment. Volunteer battalions had been created in reaction to a perceived threat of invasion by France in the late 1850s. Organised as "rifle volunteer corps", they were independent of the British Army and composed primarily of the middle class. The only change to the regiment's structure during the period of 1881-1908 occurred in 1888, when the two militia battalions of the regiment amalgamated. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Formed !Formerly |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#bdb;"|Regular |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |1st |1572 |1st Battalion, 3rd Regiment of Foot |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |2nd |1857 |2nd Battalion, 3rd Regiment of Foot |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#deb887;"|Militia |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |3rd (Militia) |1760 |1st Battalion, East Kent Militia |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |4th (Militia) |1760 |2nd Battalion, East Kent Militia |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#bbd;"|Volunteers |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |1st Volunteer |1859 |2nd Kent (East Kent) Rifle Volunteer Corps |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |2nd (The Weald of Kent) Volunteer |1860 |5th Kent (The Weald of Kent) Rifle Volunteer Corps |} ==Reorganisation== The Territorial Force (later Territorial Army) was formed in 1908, which the volunteer battalions joined, while the militia battalions transferred to the "Special Reserve". All volunteer battalions were renumbered to create a single sequential order. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Formerly |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |4th |1st Volunteer Battalion |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |5th (The Weald of Kent) |2nd (The Weald of Kent) Volunteer Battalion |} ==First World War== The Buffs fielded 15 battalions and lost over 6,000 officers and other ranks during the course of the war. The regiment's territorial components formed duplicate second and third line battalions. As an example, the three-line battalions of the 4th Buffs were numbered as the 1/4th, 2/4th, and 3/4th respectively. Many battalions of the regiment were formed as part of Secretary of State for War Lord Kitchener's appeal for an initial 100,000 men volunteers in 1914. The Special Reserve reverted to its militia designation in 1921, then to the Supplementary Reserve in 1924; however, its battalions were effectively placed in 'suspended animation'. As World War II approached, the Territorial Army was reorganised in the mid-1930s, many of its infantry battalions were converted to other roles, especially anti-aircraft. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Fate |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |4th |Absorbed 5th (The Weald of Kent) Battalion, without a change in title on 26 August 1921 |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |5th (The Weald of Kent) |Absorbed by 4th Battalion on 26 August 1921 |} ==Second World War== The Buff's expansion during the Second World War was modest compared to 1914–1918. National Defence Companies were combined to create a new "Home Defence" battalion, and in addition to this, a number of battalions and batteries of the Home Guard were affiliated to the regiment. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Formed !Served !Fate |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#ccc;"|Others |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |70th (Young Soldiers) |September 1940 |Britain |Disbanded January 1943 |} ==Post-World War II== In the immediate post-war period, the army was significantly reduced: nearly all infantry regiments had their first and second battalions amalgamated and the Supplementary Reserve disbanded. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Fate |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |1st |Amalgamated with 2nd Battalion on the 23 September 1949, without a change in title |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |2nd |Amalgamated with 1st Battalion on the 23 September 1949 |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |4th |Redesignated the 4th/5th Battalion on 1 January 1947 |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |5th |Redesignated the 4th/5th Battalion on 1 January 1947 |} ==Amalgamation== In 1956, the 5th Battalion was reformed, leading to the 4th/5th Battalion being redesignated as the 4th Battalion. The 1957 Defence White Paper stated that the Buffs was due to amalgamated with the Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment, to form the Queen's Own Buffs, The Royal Kent Regiment on the 1 March 1961. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Battalion !Fate |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |1st |Amalgamated with 1st Battalion, The Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment, to form 1st Battalion, The Queen's Own Buffs, The Royal Kent Regiment |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |4th |Transferred to the Queen's Own Buffs, The Royal Kent Regiment without a change in title |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |5th |Transferred to the Queen's Own Buffs, The Royal Kent Regiment without a change in title |} ==References== ==Sources== * Category:Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment) Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment), List of battalions Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment) Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment) Battalions
